titleStmt.title: Letter: 1886 Bishop of Liverpool’s Address. Daily Telegraph 11 December.

hi.note: This newspaper has been torn so parts are missing. I have filled in words where appropriate—Ed.

body.p: Sir,—I thank you for the short notice (in your paper of this evening) of what the Bishop of Liverpool said at the late Church of England meeting in Congress Hall, Wakefield:—viz. “That it was a delusion to suppose that anybody and everybody was fit to be a country parson.” At the same time I regret your not giving your many readers a little more of which that able, hard-working, and experienced Bishop had said in his noble and plain address on this important subject. To tell you the truth, I was so much struck with it, when reading it a few days ago, that I had half determined to make a few extracts therefrom for the columns of your paper; only I [thought] you could not find room for them at [this busy] time of Supreme Court sitting [here, but] since you have begun, I will, [follow] your example, give an extract or [two].

[The Bishop] commenced by observing, [that the best] 35 years of his ministerial [duties were spent] in purely country parishes.— [****] was not popular in an immense [****] of the rural parishes. The [****] the Church were not valued. [****] were outnumbered by the [****]-goers.—In the agricultural districts [****] disliked worldliness in the rectory or vicarage. They had no confidence in a clergyman who seemed nothing more than a clerical sportsman, or farmer, or gardener, or lawn-tennis player, or singer, or ballgoer. – – – It was utter madness to suppose that a highly ornate ritual, psalm-chanting, a surpliced choir, processions, flowers on the Communion table, and daily services, would be at once swallowed down and appreciated by an agricultural population [complet]ely unaccustomed to such things. [They want]ed spiritual food. They did not [want to be trea]ted like children, and if the [Church could n]ot provide them with something [to nourish th]eir souls, he must not be sur[prised if they] walked in the steps of their [great gra]nd-fathers and preferred [****]. – – – The Sunday [****] chief source of instruction. [****] proportion of the sermons [****] the clergymen of country [** migh
]t just as well not be preached [****] in a country pulpit was [****] sin. – – – Well-mean[ing ****] were incessantly taking [****] this to get up village concerts, [****]adings and questionable amuse[ments], and neglecting old-fashioned house to house visitation; but next to preaching the Word of God, nothing would ever do [****]h good to souls, as quiet, friendly, face-to-face dealing with individuals!
Here, in these clear and faithful remarks, is much food for thought— suitable for all parties. Verb. sap.—I am, &c.,
